column8: Jitsukawa Gakujūrō II, born as Katsujiro, was the son of a samurai family in the late Edo period. His father was a low-ranking samurai, which placed them in the middle class of Japanese society at the time. Samurai were considered part of the ruling class, but their actual wealth and living conditions varied greatly. Lower-ranking samurai like Gakujūrō's father often lived modestly. They were not wealthy, but they had a certain level of social prestige and access to education. Gakujūrō would have been expected to follow in his father's footsteps and become a samurai, but he chose to become a kabuki actor instead. His family background would have given him access to education and a relatively comfortable early life, but he would not have been considered part of the elite.
